title: GreyNoise Tags

last_post.content:
Being able to do this in JS #DuckDB (in this case in @observablehq)
```
tagsDB = DuckDBClient.of({
tags: tagsMeta,
kev: kevEntries,
cveTags: kevTagCreationDate
})
```
(those are 3 JS *arrays*)

& then being able to use 😊 SQL vs an 😒 set of chained JS map/filter + (anon)=>functions:
```
SELECT DISTINCT (cve) created_at, cve, dateAdded, (created_at - dateAdded) AS delta
FROM cveTags a
INNER JOIN kev b
ON a.cve = b.cveID
```
is just the 🐝🦵🏼.

(ref 📓) => https://observablehq.com/@greynoise/greynoise-tags

title: blocklists

last_post.content:
@learosema Check out the Oliphant blocklists by @oliphant.

I contributed its tier0.csv for new admins. It’s a subset of the pleroma.envs.net suspension list (so I can vouch for all its entries) that appears on a minimum number of other hand-picked blocklists. As of right now, an entry on tier0.csv needs to be on 11 out of 18 other hand-picked blocklists (11 “votes”) to also appear on tier0.csv. I don’t currently share the sources since not all of them would be comfortable making that public.

As of right now: 6-8 “controversial” entries are automatically excluded, and 13-15 entries with at least 7 votes each are overridden and re-inserted despite not meeting the “11 vote” threshold. Between 12 and 20 instances have been removed because they shut down or stopped federating (all subdomains/IPs are periodically auto-checked to see if they come back online). These overrides also “fuzz” the output a little to make reverse-engineering the sources slightly harder. It’s a subset of the pleroma.envs.net blocklist, not a subset of the other sources’ lists; they shouldn’t be seen as responsible for what’s on it since we get the final say.

However, the resulting list is a bit…long. It’s 331 domains (plus one fake domain) right now. That can be overwhelming to new admins. I manually pared it down to what I personally think is the “worse half”, available as FediNuke.txt.

Possible options for building your blocklist:

A. Import Tier 0 and call it a day, but hear out your members if they disagree with anything on the list. Your judgement matters, not mine; imported blocklists are merely a starting point.

B. Import FediNuke.txt, and then selectively import the rest of Tier 0 after checking each entry yourself.

C. Import Tier 0 and manually check each entry over the next few weeks, starting with entries that exist on Tier 0 but not FediNuke.

D. See what’s common between Tier 0 and the blocklist of another instance you trust. Remember that Tier 0 consists of root-domain blocks wherever it makes sense to do so, but the instance you’re comparing against might block subdomains.

E. Do something else entirely. The whole point of the Fediverse is that you don’t have to let people like me make these decisions for you.

title: the-algorithm-ml/models.py at main · twitter/the-algorithm-ml

last_post.content:
Here are some thought about the #Twitter #recsys algorithm. Not focusing on the stack. I think anyone with industry experience really does not care if it is scala, tensorflow, pytorch. A tool is a tool.
1. I was surprised by the simplicity of https://github.com/twitter/the-algorithm-ml/blob/main/projects/twhin/models/models.py. at the same time it is interesting to see they use sgd with 2 different lr. So clearly it is not an MVP.
2. Multitask learning for the ranking is great. The actual aggregation of the loss still is relatively naive but it does it.

title: GitHub - typst/typst: A new markup-based typesetting system that is powerful and easy to learn.

last_post.content:
So #pandoc has support for #typst output (https://github.com/typst/typst) as of version 3.1.2 (https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/releases/tag/3.1.2).

As far as I can tell that means that the #RMarkdown / #QuartoPub to PDF pipeline will sooner or later be able to produce high-quality output on par with LaTeX but *without* actually needing a LaTeX installation (and a lot faster at that (and less bogged down by decades of stacked-upon code (and hopefully even include less arcane error messages))).

Color me intrigued.

title: GitHub - alicezwatson/bias-in-ai-art: Uncovering Implicit Biases in AI Art: A Study of Stable Diffusion, MidJourney, and Dall-E Generators

last_post.content:
I made some good progress on my paper about uncovering implicit biases in AI art, looking at the Stable Diffusion, MidJourney, and Dall-E generators.

Specifically, I tested the following null hypotheses with MidJourney's image generation:

1️⃣ Women are not more likely to be depicted in images prompted with 'victim'.

2️⃣ Men are not more likely to be depicted in images prompted with 'violent'.

And surprise! 🎉 Both nulls were rejected.

I would love some constructive feedback or ideas on what to poke at next.
👈:blobcateyesblush:👉

Here's the GitHub repo: https://github.com/alicezwatson/bias-in-ai-art

#StableDiffusion #DallE #MidJourney #AIArt #research #gender #violence #bias #ChatGPT
